body_html:
Even if the model is complicated, if you can post it in some sort of self-contained form, that would still be helpful.

If not, here are some things to try:

  1. Get the model running on master, and see if it gives nonsense or not
  2. Construct a test case that can distinguish between "correct" and "nonsense" outputs, and then bisect commits between 0.3 and 0.4 which cause problems
  3. Dump the intermediate results of the model, and determine which layer is causing the divergence.
body_text:
Even if the model is complicated, if you can post it in some sort of self-contained form, that would still be helpful.
If not, here are some things to try:

Get the model running on master, and see if it gives nonsense or not
Construct a test case that can distinguish between "correct" and "nonsense" outputs, and then bisect commits between 0.3 and 0.4 which cause problems
Dump the intermediate results of the model, and determine which layer is causing the divergence.
body:
Even if the model is complicated, if you can post it in some sort of self-contained form, that would still be helpful.

If not, here are some things to try:

1. Get the model running on master, and see if it gives nonsense or not
2. Construct a test case that can distinguish between "correct" and "nonsense" outputs, and then bisect commits between 0.3 and 0.4 which cause problems
3. Dump the intermediate results of the model, and determine which layer is causing the divergence.
